awd_titl_txt: REU SITE: Research experiences in marine and estuarine science in the northern Gulf of Mexico
awd_abstract_narration:
The Dauphin Island Sea Laboratory (DISL) located on Dauphin Island, AL in the northern Gulf of Mexico, will host a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program. The program will bring eight undergraduates each summer to DISL to conduct independent research projects with the guidance of research mentors. The program will provide a strong integration of field and lab-based studies across disciplines and proximity to a range of ecosystems. In addition to independent research in marine science, students will participate in a series of seminars, field trips, and enrichment activities designed to develop the skills critical to a career in science. Students will present a final poster at a formal symposium, with the goal of contributing to a peer-reviewed paper and presenting their work at a scientific meeting following the summer internship. 

The theme of the DISL REU program is understanding the marine and estuarine ecosystems and living resources of the Gulf of Mexico, including research topics such as benthic ecology, fisheries and marine mammal ecology, toxicology, and biological, chemical, and physical oceanography. The program will conduct a national search for applicants and seeks to engage students who are from schools with limited research opportunities, particularly those in the Gulf Coast region. Most of the funding provided supports student stipends, housing and travel to attend the program. 

The Rutgers REU Site will provide a total of twenty-four undergraduates with internships over the three-year period. This project supports the national goals of developing the next generation of scientists and the scientific workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the project period (2019-2021, with an extension to fund additional meeting attendance and publications through August 2022), DISL hosted 24 REU students, with one additional student participating in 2021 under a supplement to mentor K. Hoadley. We focused on maintaining the positive trajectory of increasing applications from underserved and underrepresented groups, initiated diversity and inclusion training for mentors, and established a relationship with a regional journal to publish REU papers in a special theme section. The diversity and inclusion training provided a basic structure for future training and a handbook for faculty mentors, which did not previously exist at DISL. We additionally initiated participant surveys to aid program assessment. Of note, during 2020 DISL hosted one of the only in-person REU programs in the country. This effort was possible because of our relatively remote location and cancellation of other summer programs on campus, providing an abundance of housing and opportunities for social distancing. We modified our program structure and activities to retain hands-on lab experiences but accommodate virtual participation in most career development activities, field trips, and the poster symposium.

Significant achievements include increasing application numbers by 70%, maintaining regional and HBCU participation, and meeting the goal for at least 50% of participants to come from institutions with limited research opportunities. Most students met multiple metrics for underserved and underrepresented groups and 100% of students met at least one. Participants included a higher number of students who identify as American Indian and African American than in the past and included one 2-year community college, eight first-generation, and three LGBTQ+ students. Results from participant surveys indicated the program largely functioned as intended, with students gaining critical technical, career development and communication skills, as well as confidence in their abilities. Results from surveys initiated since 2019 suggest 30% of students continued to work with mentors and 60% stayed in touch with mentors, staff and other REUs after leaving the program.

Since 2019, 25 students presented posters as part of the DISL REU program Poster Symposium, 25 produced video blogs, 10 authored or co-authored peer-reviewed papers, 2 projects resulted in additional publications acknowledging REU students, and (despite COVID) 6 students presented at regional or national scientific meetings (Ocean Sciences, Coastal and Estuarine Research Federation, US HABs), giving 7 presentations in all.  In addition, 1 former REU student received a GRFP award for graduate research, 1 took a position with US Fish and Wildlife Service, 3 students started and/or completed MS programs, and 3 started PhD programs.
